text: Big question. Again, I think it's continued with my kind of theme, which I think it differs depending on the particular area of fixed income you're looking at. On the corporate credit side, I think the first decision you have to take for market neutral strategy is whether you want to include the rates component of a corporate bond. As I said before, we think it's more convenient not to. So if you think the underlying instrument, it's a corporate bond with a rates hedge. So then having done that, you've got a universe of similar corporate bonds on a rates hedge basis. The question you've got to answer then is what are the common factors within those corporate bonds? The way we do it is we define a market factor, we define sector factors, curve factors, and other common factors. And we use something that your listeners might be familiar with, a Barra-style cross-sectional factor risk approach that we've built in-house here to extract those factor returns. So once we've done that, we've got a decomposition of the returns of a bond into its spread component, its rates component, and then from there, we've got a decomposition of the returns of a bond into its spread component, for its spread component, we can decompose that into its factors, market factor, sector, curve, et cetera. Having done all of that, we can then answer the beta question. And depending on how you define it, the beta really is defined by the factor returns, really. So it's either just the market beta or it's all of those common factors and how they co-vary with the market portfolio. That's very different from just doing a statistical beta against the global ag. It's different because we're using a factor model and we're parsing out the various return drives. So it's very different from just doing a statistical beta against the global ag. And it's different because the global ag itself is an extremely rates-heavy, high-quality corporate bond plus a big chunk of treasury's benchmark. So it probably isn't that relevant for high-yield investing, or it's not the best choice of beta for high-yield strategy.
